Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Example: sūr-sõ knašš-õs nīn-õs;big-INE beautiful-INE town-INE;in a beautiful big town;

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Example: knaš neits-õn;beautiful.GEN girl-DAT;to a beautiful girl;

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Example: Vanāǟma vȯst-īz kalāmī’e-d kä’dst lešti;grandmother buy-PST.3SG fisherman-PL.GEN from flatfish.PL.PRT;Grandmother bought some flatfish from the fishermen;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Example: Ta mī-ž eņtš laps järā;3SG sell-PST.3SG own.GEN child.GEN away;S/he sold his/her child;|mī’e-d bõuvõ-bõd su’dmaļ-tõ;man-PL build-3PL mill-PRT;Men are building a mill;
Comment: The genitive case can be associated with perfective/bounded situations,  whereas partitive can be used for imperfective/unbounded situations.

Name: Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Example:
Võtā eņtš kirrõ, li tubbõ;take.IMP.2SG own.GEN ax.GEN go.IMP.2SG room.ILL;
Take your ax and go inside;
Comment: The object in the imperative clauses is typically in the genitive form. In addition,  the partitive (but also the genitive) are used with negation.

Name: Is there differential subject marking?
Example: sǟ’l lī-b ju knašī-di ǟrgi-di;there will_be-3SG PTCL beautiful-PL.PRT ox-PL.PRT;There will be beautiful oxen;|ǟrga-d attõ sǟl;ox-PL be.3PL there;The oxen are there;

Name: Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Example: Siz ne võt-īz-t võrgõ-d ja rūoik-iz-t kuod pūol;then 3PL take-PST-3PL net-PL.GEN and run-PST-3PL home.GEN towards;Then they took the nets and [they] ran towards home;

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Comment: Frequentative derivation in Livonian is marginal.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Comment: The construction 'be' + supine  form does not tend to convey an ongoing activity.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Example: Ma mūpõ matk-õb je’ddõpē’ḑõn;1SG tomorrow travel-3SG forward;Tomorrow I'll travel forward;

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Example: ta ne-iz, ku se vȯļ õbdizõ-ks sō-nd;3SG see-PST.3SG that it be.PST.3SG silvery-TRA get-ACT.PST.PTCP.SG;S/he saw that this had turn silvery;

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Example: Ta iz līeda;3SG NEG.PST.3SG find.CNG;S/he didn't find;

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Example: ne’i ku ma vȯl-ks lǭtõ-l;so as 1SG be-COND church_service-ADE;as though I would be at a church service;

Name: Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Example: ku sa ka vȯl-ks-t skūol-sõ kǟ’-nd ja opp-õn, si’z ka si’nn-õn vȯl-ks ne’i ī’ž jõvā jelāmi;if 2SG also be-COND-2SG school-INE go-ACT.PST.PTCP.SG and study-ACT.PST.PTCP.SG then also 2SG-DAT  be-COND so good living;If you would have also gone to school and studied then you would also have such good life;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Example: Sie-dā a’mmõ u’m tīe-mõst;this-PRT all.PRT be.3SG do-DEB;All this needs to be done;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Example: Laz võtā-g sīe ibīz ja pan-gõ rattõd je’ddõ;let take-JUSS.SG this.GEN horse.GEN and put-JUSS.SG carridge.PL.GEN in front;Let him/her take the horse and put [it] in front of the carridge;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Example: sa kīt-ist, laz ma vaḱt́ə-g āita uks-tā;2SG say-PST.2SG let 1SG guard-JUSS.SG granary.GEN door-PRT;You said that I should guard the door of the granary;

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Example: sīepierāst ma tǭ’-b, la’z sa mī-gõ /---/ sīe vā’škiz jarā;because_of_this 1SG want-1SG let 2SG sell-JUSS.SG this.GEN calf.GEN away;This is why I want that you would sell this calf;

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Example: Jel-īz-tõ;live-PST-2PL/3PL;you/they lived;

Name: Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Example: Siz mūndakõrd vȯst-īz-tõ būomvilliz-t luoimõ;then sometimes buy-PST-3PL cottony-PRT thread.PRT;Then sometimes cottony thread was bought;

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Comment: In Livonian,  it is more common to use laz + the jussive form.

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Example: Ni sadā-b!;now rain-3SG,;Now it is raining!;
Comment: Still,  the subject place may also be occupied,  e.g. by vī'm 'rain',  lu'm 'snow' etc.

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Example: Ta um opātiji;3SG be.3SG teacher;S/he is a teacher

Name: Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Example: Se  vȯļ/līb tä’m tidār mīez;this be.PST.3SG/will_be.3SG 3SG.GEN daugther.GEN husband; This was/will be his/her daugther’s husband;

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Example: re’bbi ja kõps;;a fox and a rabbit;|ta ist-īz ja kūld-iz;3SG sit-PST.3SG and listen-PST.3SG;S/he was sitting and listening;

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Example: ma lugū-b : ma äb lu’g;1SG read-1SG : 1SG NEG.PRS.1SG read.CNG;I read : I don’t read;

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Example: Tēg lǟ-t umbõ, äb tund-õs äb kēr-idi äb Jumal joud-õ;2PL go.2PL dead_end.ILL NEG know-CVB NEG Scripture-PL.PRT NEG God.GEN power.PRT;You are mistaken, not understanding the Scriptures nor the power of God;

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Example: tīe-mõt tīe;do-SUP.ABE work;undone work;

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Example: sie reit si’nn-õn sǭ-b iera’l-tõt jalg-õt;his time 2SG-DAT get-3SG cut_off-PASS.PST.PTCP leg-PRT;This time your leg will be cut off;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Example: lu'gg-õn;read-ACT.PST.PTCP;;|lug-dõd;read.PASS.PST.PTCP;;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Example: pan̄-dǝ̂p pàik̆ka;put-PASS.PRS.PTCP place;a place where one can put things;
Comment: In Livonian, the passive present participle can relativize the P argument but in addition to that it can also relativize obliques.

Name: Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Example: a'ili-ji;run-AG.NMLZ;a runner;|a'ili-ji i'bbi;run-AG.NMLZ horse.NOM;a running horse (lit. ‘a runner horse’);
Comment: Livonian also has a separate active present participle but it is rearly used,  the agentive nominalization tends to be used instead.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Example: Võtā eņtš kirrõ, li tubb-õ;take.IMP.2SG own.GEN ax.GEN go.IMP.2SG room-ILL;Take your axe and go inside;

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Example: Alā tīedõ kartõ;IMP.NEG.2SG work-PRT afraid.IMP.CNG;Don't be afraid of work;

Name: Are there preverbs?
Example: mǭ’zõ tappõ;down kill.INF;to kill;

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Example: sa-kutsõnd;PFX-call.ACT.PST.PTCP;have called together;
Comment: Prefixes have been taken from Latvian.

Name: Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Example: laps pie’zzimi;child.GEN wash-NMLZ;washing the child / child's washing;|laps pipā; child.GEN doll;a child's doll;

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Example: sīlda parāntimi;bridge.GEN repairing;repairing of the bridge;|Ma parānt-õb sīlda tierrõ-ks;1SG repair-1SG bridge.GEN well-TRA;I'll repair the bridge;
Comment: The genitive and partitive cases are both object cases.

Name: Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Example: pū-d attõ sūr-d;tree-PL be.3PL big-PL;the trees are big

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Example: si'zzõl : sizāl : sizāld(õ(st));;into : inside : from inside
Comment: In Livonian one can also encounter syncretism,  especially in the case of adpositions expressing external location.

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Example: ikš kalā : kakš ka'llõ;one.NOM fish.NOM : two.NOM fish.PRT, one fish: two fish

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Example: ikš kalā : kakš ka'llõ;one.NOM fish.NOM : two.NOM fish.PRT, one fish: two fish

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Example: Ānda sīe minn-õn!;give.IMP.2SG this.GEN 1SG-DAT;Give it to me!;

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Example: luggõ-mõt;read-SUP.ABE;not read;|tīe-mõt;do-SUP.ABE;undone;
Comment: The usage of the abessive form is rare. Primarily it can be found with verbs.

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Example: mõts-õ;forest-ILL;into the forest

Name: Is there a locative case that marks location?
Example: mõtsā-s;forest-INE;in the forest

Name: Is there a locative case that marks source?
Example: mõtsā-st;forest-ELA, from the forest

Name: Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Example: pȭrand-õl;floor-ALL/ADE;to the floor, on the floor;

Name: Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Comment: The external local cases occur in fossilized adverbs.

Name: Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Example: kǭjõ-ks;spoon-INS;with a spoon;|lapsõ-ks;child-INS;with a child;

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Example: Di’drõk kōgiņ perīmī’ekõks i’z ūo;Di'drõk long master-INS NEG.PST.3SG be.CNG;Di'drõk was not  master for long;perīmī’ekõks;|master-INS;with a master;

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Comment: There are almost no traces of the essive case.

Name: Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Comment: In Livonian,  the nominative and genitive forms rarely differ. However,  formally the genitive case is used in attributive constructions.

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Comment: There are no possessive suffixes.

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: There are no possessive suffixes.

Name: Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: There are no possessive suffixes.

Name: Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Example: kis;;who;|mis;;what

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Example: ne ūškad, kis...;these snake-PL who;the snakes that…;

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Example: suodākuoigī-d, kis…;war_ship-PL who;;warships that...;
Comment: However,  the usage of 'who' with inanimates might not be very common.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Example: se u’m pī’lõ-n ne’i vāgiž;it be.3SG stand-ACT.PST.PTCP.SG so still;S/he (lit. it) has been standing so still;

Name: Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Comment: There are no possessive suffixes.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Example: vanāǟma-d-õn;grandmother-PL-DAT;to the grandmothers;

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Example: kanā [ˈka.naː] 'hen' vs. kanni [ˈkan.ni] 'catkin'

Name: Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Example: ind [ˈind] ‘ardour’ vs. īnda [ˈiːn.da]  ‘price’

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Example: tapā [ˈtap.paː] 'plug' vs.  tappõ [ˈtapː.pǝ] kill.INF

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Example: tapāb [ˈtap.paːb] kill.PRS.3SG vs.  tappõ [ˈtapː.pǝ] kill.INF

Name: Are there extralong syllables?
Example: jūoksõb [ˈjuːok.ʃǝb] 'flowing'

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Example: kanā [ˈka.naː] 'hen'

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Example: amātnikā [ˈamaːt.ˌnik.kaː] 'artisan'

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Example: kana [ˈka.naˑ] 'hen'

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Example: loul [louːl] 'song, singing'

Name: Are there lowering diphthongs?
Example: kuodā [ˈkuo.daː] 'house'

Name: Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Example: kõlā [ˈkɯ.laː] 'arc'

Name: Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Example: pȯsk [pɤsːk] 'cheek'

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Example: tämpõ [ˈtæmp.pǝ] 'today' vs. tempõ [ˈtemp.pǝ] tamp.INF

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Example: krīkõ [ˈkriːk.kǝ] creak.INF

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Example: kurkšlõ [ˈkurkʃ.lǝ] croak.INF

Name: Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Example: kurkšlõ [ˈkurkʃ.lǝ] croak.INF

Name: Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Example: jaļkš [jalʲkʃ] 'foot (of the bed)'

Name: Are there palatalized dentals?
Example: kaļāj [ˈka.lʲaːi] 'smith' vs. kalā [ˈka.laː] 'fish'

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Example: tsukkõr [t͡sukː.kǝr] 'sugar'

Name: Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Example: tšoļk [ˈt͡ʃolʲk] 'slops, hogwash'

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Example: širts [ʃirts] 'apron'

Name: Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Example: giltõ [ˈgiltː.tǝ] water.INF, dip.INF

Name: Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
Example: kuoŗŗõ [ˈkuorʲː.rʲɤ] gather.INF  vs. kūoŗõb [ˈkuːo.rʲɤb] gather.PRS.3SG
